items.title: Dazi, terre rare e relazioni con la Cina: la visita a Roma del commissario europeo Maroš Šefčovič
items.description: Dazi, terre rare e relazioni con la Cina sono stati i temi centrali della visita in Italia del commissario europeo al Commercio, Maroš Šefčovič. Nella
items.body:
By:  Redazione EURACTIV Italia  |  Euractiv Italia con media e agenzie    31 Ottobre 2025|18:40             
            
                
        
    Nella foto il commissario europeo al Commercio, Maros Sefcovic, durante la sua visita in Italia avvenuta dal 30 al 31 ottobre 2025. [@MarosSefcovic/X]            
        
     
        
            
                Stampa Email Facebook X LinkedIn WhatsApp Telegram

Dazi, terre rare e relazioni con la Cina sono stati i temi centrali della visita in Italia del commissario europeo al Commercio, Maroš Šefčovič. Nella due giorni il commissario ha incontrato diversi esponenti del governo e del mondo imprenditoriale e ha partecipato giovedì a un’audizione davanti alle Commissioni riunite Esteri, Attività produttive e Politiche Ue di Senato e Camera. Il commissario UE, impegnato su due fronti delicatissimi come i dazi statunitensi e le relazioni commerciali con Pechino ha avuto incontro con il presidente di Confindustria, Emanuele Orsini, con il ministro dell’Agricoltura, della Sovranità Alimentare e delle Foreste, Francesco Lollobrigida, il ministro delle Imprese e del Made in Italy, Adolfo Urso, e il ministro degli Esteri, Antonio Tajani.
L’occasione principale dell’incontro odierno con il ministro Lollobrigida è stata la questione dei dazi statunitensi. Dal primo gennaio entreranno in vigore tariffe aggiuntive del 92 per cento su alcune esportazioni italiane verso gli Stati Uniti – fra cui la pasta – che, sommate a quelle già esistenti, portano l’aliquota complessiva al 107 per cento. Šefčovič ha sottolineato che “questa decisione, così come è stata presa, non è basata su fatti e cifre completi” e ha assicurato che Bruxelles sta “facendo del nostro meglio per presentarla loro”.
Il commissario ha confermato che l’Unione europea sostiene l’Italia nel contestare l’accusa americana di dumping, definita “sorprendente”.
“Riteniamo che il Dipartimento del Commercio non avesse informazioni adeguate o sufficientemente dettagliate da parte di alcuni produttori di pasta in Italia, e stiamo lavorando insieme per fornirle”, ha spiegato.
Lollobrigida, dal canto suo, ha ribadito l’obiettivo di una piena liberalizzazione: “Noi siamo per i rapporti di libero scambio favorevoli a un mercato che non veda la presenza di sistemi tariffari che condizionino la possibilità dello scambio di merci in entrata e in uscita. In merito agli Usa, occorre arrivare ad avere dazi zero”.

La pasta italiana finisce nel mirino dei dazi di Donald Trump
La pasta italiana, simbolo del Made in Italy nel mondo, rischia di diventare un’altra vittima delle nuove misure protezionistiche americane, dopo che il Dipartimento del Commercio degli Stati Uniti ha annunciato nei giorni scorsi l’intenzione di introdurre un super-dazio del …

Nel corso di una conferenza stampa congiunta, Šefčovič ha aggiunto che “l’accordo raggiunto a fine agosto ha portato prevedibilità e stabilità, con una de-escalation delle tensioni nelle relazioni commerciali tra Unione europea e Stati Uniti”. Tra i settori interessati, oltre alla pasta, figurano anche vino, alcolici e medicinali, per i quali l’Italia chiede un trattamento tariffario più favorevole.
Il commissario europeo ha poi dedicato ampio spazio alla questione delle terre rare e dei minerali critici, al centro della nuova strategia commerciale e industriale europea. Šefčovič ha ricordato che la sospensione di un anno delle restrizioni cinesi su tali materiali “si applicherà sia all’Unione europea che agli Stati Uniti”, aggiungendo che “l’accordo raggiunto tra Stati Uniti e Cina su questa questione è erga omnes”, quindi probabilmente applicato a tutti e, naturalmente, anche all’UE.

La Commissione UE accoglie con prudenza l'intesa tra Stati Uniti e Cina
L’Unione europea accoglie con prudenza l’accordo annunciato tra Stati Uniti e Cina che prevede una riduzione dei dazi americani in cambio dell’impegno di Pechino a rafforzare la repressione del traffico di fentanyl. La Commissione europea, pur non commentando negoziati commerciali …

Nel colloquio con il ministro Urso, è stato affrontato il tema della diversificazione delle filiere industriali e della riduzione della dipendenza dai fornitori asiatici. L’Italia, forte del suo tessuto manifatturiero avanzato, mira a proteggere le esportazioni a elevato contenuto tecnologico e a contribuire al rilancio della “sovranità tecnologica” europea.
Šefčovič ha sottolineato che solo il 50 per cento delle domande di licenza per esportare terre rare dall’UE è stato “correttamente elaborato” dalle autorità cinesi, con conseguenze dirette sulle capacità produttive europee. “Non abbiamo avuto un’esperienza molto positiva con il rilascio di licenze di esportazione per le terre rare”, ha spiegato, confermando che Bruxelles sta avviando “colloqui ufficiali ad alto livello sui controlli delle esportazioni” con Pechino.

Un accordo tra Trump e Xi non salverà l'Europa dalla morsa delle superpotenze
Quando il presidente Trump siederà al tavolo con il presidente Xi Jinping a margine del vertice di questa settimana in Corea del Sud, nessun europeo sarà presente. Eppure gli interessi europei sono decisamente in bilico. L’incontro giunge in un momento …

Dopo l’incontro con Tajani, il commissario ha proposto la possibilità di un “acquisto comune di materie prime essenziali” da parte dell’Unione europea, da stoccare in Europa per ridurre la vulnerabilità del blocco. Tajani ha suggerito che l’Italia potrebbe ospitare un sito di stoccaggio di questo tipo.
Sul versante diplomatico, la visita ha rilanciato anche il tema del rapporto con la Cina, considerato parte integrante della strategia commerciale europea. Šefčovič ha annunciato che “il ministro del Commercio cinese, Wang Wentao, ha accettato l’invito a Bruxelles” per discutere di esportazioni e controlli sulle terre rare.

items.title: Il partito centrista D66 vince le elezioni olandesi
items.description: Il partito centrista D66 ha vinto le elezioni olandesi in modo schiacciante, ha previsto venerdì l’agenzia di stampa locale ANP, affermando che
items.body:
By:  Redazione EURACTIV Italia con AFP    31 Ottobre 2025|17:56             
            
                
        
    Nella foto il leader del partito Democratici 66 (D66) Rob Jetten. [Facebook]            
        
     
        
            
                Stampa Email Facebook X LinkedIn WhatsApp Telegram

Il partito centrista D66 ha vinto le elezioni olandesi in modo schiacciante, ha previsto venerdì l’agenzia di stampa locale ANP, affermando che il conteggio dei voti ha dimostrato che il leader di estrema destra Geert Wilders non è riuscito a colmare il divario.
Ciò metterebbe il leader del D66 Rob Jetten sulla buona strada per diventare il più giovane leader della quinta economia più grande dell’UE, ma vi saranno probabilmente lunghe trattative per la coalizione.
Le proiezioni dell’ANP sono state immediatamente citate da numerosi organi di informazione olandesi, tra cui l’emittente pubblica NOS.

Gli elettori olandesi segnalano che il centro europeo è tutt’altro che morto
L’inaspettato abbandono, da parte degli elettori olandesi, dell’esponente dell’estrema destra Geert Wilders alle elezioni di mercoledì (29 ottobre) non rappresenta una prova definitiva, ma in un momento in cui gli estremismi politici sembravano inarrestabili in tutto il continente, il sorprendente …

Con una sola circoscrizione e i voti postali all’estero ancora da contare, Jetten ha un vantaggio di 15.155 voti su Wilders.
All’Aia è già in corso lo scrutinio dei voti per corrispondenza, ma il risultato non sarà reso noto prima di lunedì sera. Storicamente, gli espatriati hanno votato per partiti più centristi e di sinistra. Alle ultime elezioni del 2023, il D66 ha superato il PVV di quasi 3.000 voti postali.
La vittoria elettorale significa che D66 prenderà il comando nella formazione di una coalizione. “Il vincitore generalmente propone un candidato esplorativo, qualcuno che conduca un’esplorazione iniziale di una potenziale coalizione”, ha dichiarato a RTL Nieuws Julien van Ostaaijen, professore associato di amministrazione pubblica all’Università di Tilburg . “Se gli altri partiti non hanno obiezioni sostanziali nei confronti di questa persona, la proposta viene generalmente seguita”.

De Kiesraad beslist niet het ANP, wat een arrogantie om daar niet op te wachten. Maar al wordt D66 de grootste, de PVV zal Nederland niet laten afbreken door Jetten cum suis en ons vanaf dag één met volle kracht 26 zetels sterk verzetten tegen zijn links-liberale wanbeleid! 💪
— Geert Wilders (@geertwilderspvv) October 31, 2025

Intanto, il leader del PVV, Wilders, ha risposto criticamente su X all’annuncio dell’ANP secondo cui D66 ha vinto le elezioni. “Decide il Consiglio elettorale, non l’ANP”, ha scritto su X.
Il leader del PVV ritiene che non aspettare sia segno di “arroganza”. Wilders ha già annunciato che si opporrà fermamente al partito. “Ma anche se il D66 diventasse il partito più grande, il PVV non permetterà che i Paesi Bassi vengano distrutti e si opporrà fermamente alla sua cattiva gestione progressista di sinistra, con 26 seggi fin dal primo giorno”, scrive Wilders.
Qui l’articolo originale di Afp
[a cura di Simone Cantarini]

items.title: Tra mare e terra nasce “Sud Adriatico”
items.description:
Il nuovo progetto per il ripristino del paesaggio marino e costiero della Puglia meridionale 
The post Tra mare e terra nasce “Sud Adriatico&#82
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie Per il ripristino del paesaggio marino e costiero della Puglia meridionale Difesa dall’erosione costiera causata dalle mareggiate, maggiore sicurezza contro gli effetti della crisi climatica, recupero delle popolazioni ittiche di interesse commerciale, assorbimento del carbonio, produzione di ossigeno. Questi sono solo alcuni degli effetti, i cosiddetti servizi ecosistemici, gratuitamente garantiti da un paesaggio marino e costiero in buona salute in cui dune sabbiose e fondali di posidonia e coralligeno sono integri e vitali. Comunità coinvolte per assicurare entro il 2030 una rete ecologicamente connessa ed efficacemente gestita di habitat protetti Per assicurare alla comunità questi servizi ha preso il via il progetto “Sud Adriatico-ripristino del paesaggio marino e costiero della Puglia meridionale” con il kick-off meeting del 28-29 ottobre al Palazzo Granafei-Nervegna di Brindisi. Il kick-off meeting del 28-29 ottobre al Palazzo Granafei-Nervegna di Brindisi Tra i partner il WWF Italia e il WWF Mediterraneo (leader di progetto), il Parco Naturale Regionale delle Dune Costiere, il Consorzio di Gestione di Torre Guaceto, il Comune di Lecce con il Parco Naturale Regionale Bosco Paludi di Rauccio, la Riserva Naturale Statale de Le Cesine/Oasi WWF e il Comune di Vernole, la Stazione Zoologica Anton Dohrn, il DISTAV (Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, dell’Ambiente e della Vita) dell’Università di Genova, e la Regione Puglia/Assessorato all’Ambiente. Per i prossimi 5 anni i partner saranno impegnati nelrivitalizzare, in un’estensione di circa 52.000 ettari, almeno 1.000 ettari di habitat prioritari marino-costieri, capitalizzando su interventi passati e sulle buone pratiche del territorio per creare una rete di protezione efficace ecologicamente connessa e ricucire gli ‘strappi’ prodotti dal degrado e dagli impatti umani. Le azioni per proteggere la Posidonia Le azioni del progetto prevedono interventi di ripristino e protezione di Posidonia, coralligeno e dune costiere e la gestione sostenibile delle attività a mare. Chiave sarà il forte coinvolgimento della comunità locale che diventerà custode del territorio: tutti gli attori, università e istituzioni locali verranno coinvolti durante l’intera durata del progetto per instaurare una gestione partecipativa del territorio che garantisca benefici socio-economici, anche in termini di adattamento e mitigazione climatica. Si contribuirà così alla Strategia per la Biodiversità e alla Legge sul Ripristino della Natura (Nature Restoration Law) dell’Unione Europea, uno strumento fondamentale entrato in vigore nel 2024 che punta a rivitalizzare almeno il 20% degli ecosistemi marini degradati entro il 2030. Tra questi le praterie di fanerogame marine, come Posidonia oceanica, sono tra gli habitat più colpiti: considerata il polmone del Mare Nostrum, la Posidonia ha perso negli ultimi 50 anni quasi il 35% della sua estensione. Un ‘alleato’ che in questi ultimi decenni abbiamo trattato molto male: queste piante, infatti, producono fino a 20 litri di ossigeno al giorno per ogni metro quadrato e immagazzinano carbonio 35 volte più velocemente di una foresta tropicale, anche per lunghi periodi, persino secoli o millenni e in maniera estremamente efficiente. La loro presenza, inoltre, garantisce la protezione delle coste riducendo del 20% l’energia delle onde e ospita oltre 50 specie ittiche di interesse commerciale. Il progetto fa parte del programma internazionale ELSP – Endangered Landscape & Seascape Programme finanziato dalla fondazione Arcadia.

items.title: Ponte sullo Stretto, la Corte dei Conti difende le tasse dei cittadini
items.description:
La Corte dei Conti ha bocciato mercoledì la delibera CIPESS (n. 41/2025) relativa al progetto del Ponte sullo Stretto di Messina
The post Ponte sullo
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie La Corte dei Conti ha bocciato mercoledì la delibera CIPESS (n. 41/2025) relativa al progetto del Ponte sullo Stretto di Messina, negando il visto di legittimità all’opera da 13,5 miliardi di euro. Una decisione che conferma le gravi criticità segnalate dalle associazioni ambientaliste alla magistratura contabile e che tutela le tasse dei cittadini che il governo ha deciso di destinare ad un intervento che non sta in piedi dal punto di vista progettuale, ambientale, economico e procedurale. Le due memorie della Corte dei Conti Greenpeace Italia, Legambiente, Lipu e WWF Italia, avevano presentato alla Corte dei Conti due dettagliate memorie in cui evidenziavano le molteplici irregolarità del progetto: dalla violazione delle normative europee e nazionali in materia ambientale, all’insostenibilità economica dell’opera, fino alle criticità procedurali che hanno caratterizzato l’intero iter autorizzativo. Bocciato dal primo soggetto terzo chiamato a pronunciarsi “La Corte dei Conti ha confermato ciò che sosteniamo da anni: il progetto del Ponte sullo Stretto è un’opera insostenibile sotto ogni profilo” dichiarano congiuntamente le quattro associazioni. Le associazioni aggiungono: “Il primo soggetto ‘terzo’ chiamato a pronunciarsi sul Ponte non ha potuto fare altro che evidenziarne tutte le problematiche irrisolte. I magistrati contabili hanno rilevato criticità fondamentali: dalle coperture economiche incerte, all’affidabilità delle stime di traffico, dalla conformità alle normative ambientali e antisismiche, fino alla violazione delle regole europee sul superamento del 50% del costo iniziale del progetto senza nuova gara d’appalto. Tutto l’iter seguito dal Governo Meloni è stato caratterizzato da continue forzature che non sono mai state risolte, ma che si è tentato di superare con ulteriori forzature, come i continui voti di fiducia per aggirare la discussione e il confronto in Parlamento, finendo per determinare un ‘mostro’ giuridico con pesanti elementi di anticostituzionalità”. Vizi istruttori e forzature Le associazioni ricordano che nella memoria presentata a metà settembre alla Corte avevano messo in evidenza proprio questi aspetti cruciali: “Avevamo contestato, oltre ai vizi istruttori relativi alla procedura di Valutazione di impatto ambientale (VIA) e alla Valutazione di incidenza (VInca), in violazione delle direttive comunitarie, l’utilizzo strumentale dei motivi imperativi di rilevante interesse pubblico (IROPI), con la ridicola forzatura di definire il Ponte come ‘opera militare’ per aggirare i vincoli ambientali. Avevamo sollevato dubbi sull’assegnazione dell’opera senza bando di gara internazionale, in contrasto con le norme europee sulla concorrenza”. Costi reali incerti “Ancora più grave – proseguono le associazioni – è l’incertezza sui costi reali dell’opera, che già oggi partono da 13,5 miliardi, ma che potrebbero lievitare drammaticamente, come sempre accade per le grandi opere in Italia. La relazione costi-benefici presentata dal Governo si basa su calcoli del tutto irrealistici sull’incremento del PIL e sui flussi di traffico previsti”. Carenze progettuali irrisolte Greenpeace Italia, Legambiente, Lipu e WWF Italia sottolineano inoltre come il progetto presenti carenze progettuali ancora irrisolte. Mancano studi sismici fondamentali, non sono stati completati test di tenuta essenziali e troppe decisioni vengono rinviate al progetto esecutivo. La Corte dei Conti ha evidenziato che manca persino il parere del Consiglio Superiore dei Lavori Pubblici sul progetto definitivo e quello dell’Autorità dei Trasporti sul piano tariffario. Tutte questioni già ampiamenti illustrate e oggetto di due ricorsi amministrativi e tre reclami alla Commissione Europea tuttora pendenti. Il governo non forzi la mano “Le reazioni scomposte del Governo contro la magistratura contabile rappresentano un’anomalia costituzionale senza precedenti, che apre un conflitto evidente tra l’esecutivo e chi è chiamato dalla Costituzione a controllare la sostenibilità economica degli atti. Ricordiamo che quegli atti sono finanziati con le tasse dei cittadini” dichiarano con durezza le associazioni. Le quattro organizzazioni ambientaliste ribadiscono che il Ponte sullo Stretto rappresenta uno spreco insostenibile di risorse pubbliche che potrebbero essere impiegate per le reali esigenze – anche infrastrutturali – del Sud e dell’intero Paese. Se il Governo manifestasse l’intenzione di forzare la mano e procedere comunque con una delibera del Consiglio dei ministri ignorando la bocciatura, le associazioni sono pronte a reagire: “Una eventuale forzatura istituzionale di questa portata rappresenterebbe una grave violazione dello Stato di diritto e minerebbe la credibilità del nostro Paese in Europa. Se ciò dovesse avvenire non esiteremo a portare la questione davanti alla Corte di Giustizia Europea per la violazione delle norme comunitarie in materia ambientale, di concorrenza e di corretta gestione delle risorse pubbliche. Un governo che procede contro i rilievi della magistratura contabile si assume una responsabilità politica e giuridica enorme che ricadrebbe anche sul Parlamento”. 1 Aprile 2023 40 anni di campi antibracconaggio sullo Stretto di Messina Ieri capitale del bracconaggio, oggi ad accogliere rapaci e cicogne in migrazione ci sono binocoli e macchine fotografiche Premiate le forze dell'ordine 27 Maggio 2023 Dossier di Kyoto Club, Lipu e WWF sul Ponte di Messina Il progetto del Ponte ad unica campata conferma l'insostenibilità dal punto di vista ambientale, economico-finanziario e sociale dell’opera. 2 Dicembre 2023 Lo Stretto di Messina non si tocca Per il WWF il Ponte sullo Stretto è un'operazione strumentale e senza fondamento Oggi a Messina manifestazione nazionale 8 Novembre 2023 Il ponte di Messina è una cambiale in bianco Confermati i timori del WWF sui costi ambientali ed economico-finanziari del progetto Ponte

items.title: Clima Ingiusto
items.description: È una domanda che Legambiente storicamente si è spesso posta e che dobbiamo porci anche oggi: come possiamo rimuovere gli ostacoli che impediscono ch
items.body:
31 Ottobre 2025

Vittorio Cogliati Dezza

31 Ottobre 2025

Economia e sostenibilità

Crisi climatica

Clima Ingiusto

31 Ottobre 2025

Vittorio Cogliati Dezza

31 Ottobre 2025

Economia e sostenibilità

Crisi climatica

È una domanda che Legambiente storicamente si è spesso posta e che dobbiamo porci anche oggi: come possiamo rimuovere gli ostacoli che impediscono che ciò che è giusto ambientalmente lo sia anche socialmente?
Parte da qui il libro Clima Ingiusto, che ho scritto con Giovanni Carrosio (pubblicato da Donzelli) e presentato all’Assemblea dei Circoli.
Con Giovanni ci siamo posti il problema del rapporto storico tra giustizia ambientale e giustizia sociale, e, cogliendo le diverse interdipendenze, abbiamo provato ad argomentare perché giustizia ambientale e sociale “sono condannate a marciare insieme”.
La sfida più urgente ce l’abbiamo oggi nel contrasto alla crisi climatica. Innanzitutto perché la crisi climatica è un moltiplicatore di disuguaglianze, ogni evento estremo e distruttivo riduce ulteriormente le capacità di resilienza dei più vulnerabili. E poi perché oggi le politiche di decarbonizzazione, nella produzione e nei consumi, non sono pensate a misura degli ultimi e penultimi, rispettando quanto già diceva don Milani: “nulla è più ingiusto che fare parti uguali tra persone disuguali”. Inoltre, da quando l’energia è diventata, per effetto delle privatizzazioni imposte dal neo-liberismo, un bene di mercato e l’accesso ai servizi energetici non è più un diritto di cittadinanza, si è creato un nuovo rischio sociale: la vulnerabilità energetica.
Dobbiamo allora partire dal fatto che oggi i rischi energetico-climatici “non sono semplicemente una variante dei rischi sociali tradizionali (lavoro, salute, istruzione, abitazione, mobilità …), ma rappresentano un paradigma nuovo”, che richiede politiche energetiche e climatiche strutturali, preventive e transettoriali.
Per passare dalla teoria alle politiche e alle azioni, secondo questo nuovo paradigma, nel libro proviamo a disegnare quale potrebbe essere il welfare energetico climatico. E, viaggiando attraverso esperienze che già si stanno realizzando nei territori, proviamo ad individuare una mappa possibile di indicatori per costruire pratiche sociali e ambientali che quel nuovo welfare comincino a realizzare, dando centralità ai luoghi e alle persone nei luoghi.
Di nuovo, la sfida climatica ci conferma che serve una visione strategica, ma serve anche il coraggio e la voglia di inventare pratiche sociali in grado di rispondere ai nuovi bisogni e ai nuovi rischi, ambientali e sociali, che colpiscono i più vulnerabili.
Buona lettura.

Vittorio Cogliati Dezza

Ambientalista, insegnante, Vittorio Cogliati Dezza, impegnato in Legambiente dagli anni 80, ne è stato presidente nazionale dal 2007 al 2015. Oggi è membro del Coordinamento del Forum Disuguaglianze e Diversità e si occupa di giustizia ambientale e sociale.

items.title: Festa dell’albero
items.description: Ogni anno festeggiamo gli alberi e il loro fondamentale contributo alla vita. Unisciti alle nostre iniziative: dal 21 al 23 novembre 2025  previste p
items.body:
31 Ottobre 2025

Legambiente

31 Ottobre 2025

Campagne in evidenza

Biodiversità , Educazione

Festa dell’albero

31 Ottobre 2025

Legambiente

31 Ottobre 2025

Campagne in evidenza

Biodiversità , Educazione

Ogni anno festeggiamo gli alberi e il loro fondamentale contributo alla vita. Unisciti alle nostre iniziative: dal 21 al 23 novembre 2025  previste piantumazioni in tutta Italia per difendere le nostre città dalla crisi climatica.  
Il 21, 22, 23  novembre 2025 unisciti a noi per chiedere città più verdi e resilienti!
Gli alberi sono i nostri più grandi alleati contro la crisi climatica. In particolare nelle aree urbane, dove entro il 2050 si stima vivrà il 70% della popolazione mondiale, il loro contributo è fondamentale. Migliorano la stabilità dei terreni contro il dissesto idrogeologico, incrementano la permeabilizzazione del suolo contribuendo a mitigare gli effetti degli eventi climatici estremi, trattengono gli inquinanti atmosferici (le polveri sottili), attutiscono i rumori fino al 70% e assorbono CO2.  La vegetazione in città riduce l’effetto “isola di calore”; se posizionati nelle vicinanze degli edifici, gli alberi possono ridurre la necessità di utilizzo dei condizionatori d’aria con un risparmio di energia stimato dal 20 al 50%.
Nonostante la messa a dimora di alberi sia una tra le nature based solutions più trascurate, rappresenta la più efficace opportunità per migliorare la salute pubblica e il benessere nelle nostre città, protagoniste indiscutibili delle necessarie politiche di adattamento e mitigazione ai cambiamenti climatici.
Grazie all’impegno di volontarie e volontari  come te e alla partecipazione di numerosi istituti scolastici, la Festa dell’Albero è giunta alla sua trentesima edizione!
Ti aspettiamo! 
Stiamo lavorando al calendario degli eventi che pubblicheremo nei prossimi giorni. Torna a trovarci per scoprire l’iniziativa più vicina a te.
Per info: campagne@legambiente.it
 
Festa dell’Albero è una campagna realizzata con il supporto di:

items.title: Synergistic analysis of climate and anthropogenic impacts on NPP dynamics in India’s Western Ghats using geodetector
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 31 October 2025

Synergistic analysis of climate and anthropogenic impacts on NPP dynamics in India’s Western Ghats using geodetector
                    Sanjay Kumar1 nAff2, Jyothika Karkala1, Joyal Arya1 & …Rajiv Kumar Chaturvedi1 Show authors

Scientific Reports

volume 15, Article number: 38252 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate-change ecologyClimate-change impactsEnvironmental health

AbstractThe importance of integrating climate resilience into conservation efforts to safeguard the Western Ghats, one of the hottest hotspots in the world, is underscored by our findings. The research was designed to provide an integrated approach to help preserve the ecological productivity in a biodiversity sensitive area. The study investigates the dynamics of terrestrial productivity, examining its trends over time (2001–2023) and identifying the various factors that influence it, a topic that has been understudied in this biodiversity hotspot. In 2019, Net Primary Productivity (NPP) results experienced significant declines across all land cover types, with the decline starting in 2015 when forest NPP dropped by 0.24 and cropland by 0.1 kg C m\(^{-2}\) year\(^{-1}\). The NPP steadily recovered the following year, especially in the croplands. The factor detector q value indicated the degree of influence of each factor as vegetation parameters (\(58.96\%\)), climatic indicators (\(21.97\%\)), anthropogenic factor (\(17.39\%\)), and topographic condition (\(1.68\%\)). Results from the innovative approach to assess spatial heterogeneity emphasize the influence of the combinations of Land Use Land Cover (LULC) with Fraction of Photosynthetically Active Radiation (FPAR), Leaf Area Index (LAI), Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI), Land Surface Temperature (LST), and Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI), followed by LST interacting with FPAR, and NDVI with LAI, had the greatest impact on NPP. The study employs multiple regression to evaluate the effects of variables, the Mann–Kendall method for trend analysis, and Geo-detector for spatial variation.

IntroductionThe role of forests in regulating climate, transfer of energy, water balance, and carbon cycle by exchanging huge quantities of carbon with the atmosphere is indispensable in the terrestrial ecosystem1,2. Roughly 31% of the land area on Earth is made up of forests3 with the ability to absorb higher amounts of carbon in comparison to all the other ecosystems combined while providing ecosystem services worth trillions of dollars. Forests not only provide a spectrum of benefits but also possess the power to withstand and mitigate climate change4. The sustenance of the forest ecosystem is defined by the primary productivity. The rate at which autotrophic organisms along with plants convert solar energy into organic compounds through the process of photosynthesis in an ecosystem is the Gross Primary Productivity(GPP). The NPP is the GPP minus the rate at which some of these compounds are used through cellular respiration5. Globally, the GPP between the atmosphere and land makes up for the largest carbon flux about 130 Gt C year\(^{-1}\) as photosynthesis fixes the carbon determining the potential for carbon absorption2. NPP serves as a popularly utilized pivotal marker for the assessment of ecological security and as a measure of vegetation dynamics1.Climate change is contributing to the unfortunate decline in the productivity of forests6. Climate change marked by changing temperature (TEMP), and precipitation (PPT) conditions accompanied by a rise in \(CO_2\) affects a spectrum of forest services7. The continued human activity has been contributing to the rise of long-lived greenhouse gases and the build-up of these gases is likely to increase the surface air temperature by 1.5–4.5 °C in this century. Global NPP of the terrestrial ecosystem is bound to be affected by a change in climate of such a magnitude8. A key contributor to the negative feedback on climate warming is the enhanced vegetation productivity driven by the increasing concentration of carbon dioxide(\(CO_2\)) although there is a lack of clarity in the temporal dynamics of the process9. Lately, a climate-driven substantial change in forest ecosystems, characterized by an increase in the frequency and severity of disturbance regimes, has significantly impacted the productivity of ecosystem services. There is a high probability that the climate-induced disturbances could overshadow the ecological resilience of forests which possibly could perpetually shift the ecosystem balance10. A noteworthy number of interdependent climate factors fuel a series of short-term or permanent complications and ill effects on natural and human systems are the climate extremes such as drought, heavy precipitation, and heatwaves which can co-occur across the globe11,12,13,14,15,16,17,18. Apart from posing a threat to society, the concurrent extreme climate events are a danger to the forest ecosystem as hot and dry weather inhibits the capacity to suppress and can kick start wildfires causing extensive environmental impacts, forest mortality, and fire damages11. Another facet of forest stress comes from urban land expansion, as the impervious surface takes over the natural vegetation on the city-to-country scale, studies have indicated a reduction in the terrestrial NPP19.The current scenario of forest productivity has driven the conceptualization and application of multiple techniques to assess it. Among the land cover types, forests prove to be the most productive which has an average GPP of 2.0 kg C m\(^{-2}\) year\(^{-1}\) while cropland and grassland are estimated to be 1.8 and 1.5 kg C m\(^{-2}\) year\(^{-1}\) respectively2. Global biosphere productivity represents the most significant absorption flux of atmospheric carbon dioxide (\(CO_2\)) and is crucial for understanding both historical and future carbon cycles20. The temporal and spatial components of the NPP in the source region of the Yangtze River in China were carried out using data from the Carnegie-Ames-Stanford Approach model. The impact of climatic factors was studied and the result highlighted the key factors as temperature and precipitation on an inter-annual time scale and human activities in the downstream region1. Net ecosystem productivity (NEP) is fundamental to the forest carbon sink, and comparing NEP between natural and planted forests can aid in reaching carbon neutrality. As a result of soil fertilizer and higher stand age, the NEP in natural forests was lower than in planted ones. At the same time, as the mean annual air temperature decreased due to latitudinal variations, the GPP dropped in both the planted and natural forests21. The impact of meteorological and biophysical parameters on the NPP in the tropical deciduous forest of India showed that a decrease in NPP was attributed to rise in temperature combined with vapour pressure deficit22. The significant effect of precipitation on the NPP was revealed when studying the NPP in the forest plantation in India. Also, the modeled data tends to underestimate the value in comparison to the field-estimated data23. A study in India demonstrated that an 18.51% increase in LAI from 2001 to 2019 did not result in increased carbon uptake caused by warming constraints. It also revealed that in forests which are temporally consistent, a 6.19% decrease in NPP occurred despite a 6.75% increase in LAI24. The use of remote sensing, Residual Trend analysis, and correlation analysis showed that precipitation is the primary driver of NPP over 72% of the area in India. At the same time, temperature and solar radiation influenced NPP in the Himalayas and forested regions, respectively with a slight decline caused by human activities25. The geographic detector model (GDM) is utilized to understand the relative contribution of multiple climatic factors on vegetation activities while detecting the heterogeneity in spatial stratification26,27,28.Globally, 420 million hectares of forest land have vanished since 1990 from the conversion to anthropogenic uses. During the period 2015–2020, 10 million hectares of forest were cut down every year which is less than in the 1900s, when 16 million hectares per year were lost3. To safeguard and elevate the forest carbon sinks, multiple efforts for policy development and economic incentives are introduced such as the advancement in the carbon offset projects for forests on the global scale, and the Bonn Challenge for the restoration of landscape4. India is determined to expand its tree and forest cover creating an add-on of nearly 3 billion tonnes of carbon sink by the year 203029. Western Ghats, well known for its distinctive ecological and biophysical processes, is one of the ancient mountains. It stands at eighth position on the list of the world’s hottest hotspots due to its biodiversity. Unfortunately, the high-altitude montane forest ecosystem that controls the weather pattern of the monsoon in India is under threat due to the stress on habitat and climate change. Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 15 “Life on land” of the United Nations (UN) encourages the promotion, restoration, and protection of the land. Achieving the SDG will be harmed if the downward trend in ecosystem and biodiversity persists3. The changing natural vegetation as a direct result of climate change modifies vegetation productivity. Reversing the fragmentation of forests is more of an impossible task with a focus on biodiversity loss along with encroachment activity and increased population pressure on the forest edges3. There is a lack of clarity when decoding the underlying mechanism and bringing remote sensing into play renders a resourceful and convenient channel for estimating NPP. Although being a sensitive zone, accompanied with growing anthropogenic activities, not enough research has been carried out in this region to understand the climate change dynamics. The study aims to understand the spatiotemporal aspect of the trend in NPP in the Western Ghats from 2001 to 2023. The GDM provides a multi dimensional look at the relationship between the various explanatory variables and NPP. It is useful in not only determining the magnitude but also the potential to independently influence the target variable. The influence of climatic parameters, vegetation indices, topography, and anthropogenic activities forms the focus of the research.ResultsThe combined impact of variables can be categorized as vegetation parameters (EVI, NDVI, LAI, FPAR), climate indicators (Precipitation, Temperature, LST), anthropogenic factors (LULC), and topographic condition (slope) in this section. The q value is a measure of the magnitude of the driving force determined by the factor detector. The range of the q value is from 0 to 1. It signifies the 100 x q% of how the independent variable can explain the change in NPP. The statistical significance is denoted by the p value. The result of the MK test is given as z value based on which the significance of the trend is assessed.Spatial association of NPP with explanatory variablesThe distribution of NPP indicates that the value in the southern states of Kerala, Tamil Nadu, and Karnataka prominently populated by wet evergreen forests are significantly higher in comparison to the NPP in Goa, Maharashtra, and Gujarat which have moist deciduous and semi-evergreen forests (Fig. S1). The NPP around the Eravikulam forest region is seen to be reasonably consistent throughout owing to the higher elevation and closeness to the equator, and evergreen vegetation resulting in year-round photosynthesis. The average NPP peaked in 2011 and 2022 at 0.95 kg C m\(^{-2}\) year\(^{-1}\), with notable drops observed during 2003–2004, 2009–2010, and in 2012 and 2014. A significant decline occurred from 2017 to 2019 when NPP reached as low as 0.73 kg C m\(^{-2}\) year\(^{-1}\) (Fig. 1).Fig. 1The evolution of the mean NPP in the Western Ghats from 2001 to 2023.Full size imageTable 1 The annual average values of NPP and each explanatory variable highlighting the minimum and maximum values.Full size tableDecreased rainfall in 2002 (annual average of 143.15 mm) led to the fall of EVI, NDVI, LAI, and FPAR, in the following years of 2003 and 2004 where NPP also dropped to 0.83 (kg C m\(^{-2}\) year\(^{-1}\)). At the same time, a rise in LST was recorded. Similar conditions were observed periodically over the years. Consequently, as PPT increased in the following years, all the above-mentioned PPT dependent variables also increased and NPP levels were recovered.A huge decrease in NPP was observed in 2019 when it reached an annual average of 0.73 kg C m\(^{-2}\) year\(^{-1}\). This change can be attributed to continuous low rainfall without respite since 2015 which steered a reduction of vegetation parameters in 2016. In the same period, the yearly maximum of TEMP and LST peaked at 30.3 \(^\circ\)C and 41 \(^\circ\)C, respectively causing heat stress, increased respiration rate, and creating feasible conditions for NPP to drop. However the NPP rose to a normal level after 2019 as PPT picked up followed by improvements in the other variables. Since 2019, LST has seen a declining trend (Table 1).Response of NPP to land use transitionsDuring the first five years of the century, the average NPP in the forest was 1.23 kg C m\(^{-2}\) year\(^{-1}\) which decreased to 1.11 kg C m\(^{-2}\) year\(^{-1}\) in the last 5 years of the study, marking a decline despite an increase in forest area by 9432.07 sqkm, or 1.93% (Table 2). The total mean NPP comes up to 1.17 kg C m\(^{-2}\) year\(^{-1}\), with a maximum (in 2002) and minimum (in 2019) amounting to 1.33 and 0.96 kg C m\(^{-2}\) year\(^{-1}\) respectively. The change in area is not prominent with only a decrease of about 2100 sqkm when the NPP dropped from 1.05 to 0.95 kg C m\(^{-2}\) year\(^{-1}\). The mean NPP in shrublands, urban area, and barren land is 0.85, 0.57, and 0.26 kg C m\(^{-2}\) year\(^{-1}\) respectively. PPT interactions with other variables such as TEMP, LULC, and vegetation indices (EVI, NDVI) consistently show a nonlinear enhancement with combined effect (\(WG_C\)) greater than the sum of individual effects \(WG_A + WG_B = 0.22\) (Table 6). Interactions involving TEMP mostly display bi-variable enhancement, with \(WG_C\) values such as \(TEMP \cap \, LULC, WG_C = 0.67\), which is greater than both \(WG_A = 0.18\) and \(WG_B = 0.53\) but less than \(WG_A + WG_B = 0.71\). An exception is TEMP and slope, showing a uni-variable weaken, with \(WG_C = 0.13\) falling between \(WG_A = 0.18\) and \(WG_B = 0.04\). LULC interactions generally exhibit bi-variable enhancement, as seen with LULC and EVI, where \(WG_C = 0.70\) is greater than \(WG_A = 0.53\) and \(WG_B = 0.37\) but less than \(WG_A + WG_B = 0.90\). Similar patterns are observed with other vegetation indices such as for \(EVI \cap \, NDVI, WG_C = 0.57\) is greater than \(WG_A = 0.37\) and \(WG_B = 0.50\) but less than \(WG_A + WG_B = 0.87\), and for \(NDVI \cap \, LST, WG_C = 0.66\) is greater than \(WG_A = 0.50\) and \(WG_B = 0.47\) but less than \(WG_A + WG_B = 0.96\) (Tables S6 and S7).Table 6 The explanatory power of each variable individually obtained (\(WG_A = B_{WG}(A')\), \(WG_B = B_{WG}(A^{''})\)) and the intersection of two variable (\(WG_C = B_{WG}(A') \cap B_{WG}(A^{''})\)) results in altering conclusions. The “estimate” value of the MLR denotes to what extent the NPP changes for every unit change in the variable value. The maximum value of the estimate was in 2011 for NDVI where every unit change in NDVI resulted in 1.87 units of increase in NPP. At the same time, in 2011 EVI had a negative impact on NPP with a value of \(-0.83\). The intercept value represents the contribution of NPP under the assumption that all other variables have no influence forms the baseline for NPP. Through the years, PPT, NDVI, and LAI have been consistently positive and significant indicating that an increase in these variables will result in a higher NPP. The variables with significant negative consequences are EVI and LST. (b) The t-value determines the significance of the statistics.Full size imageDiscussionRainfall has proven to be a crucial factor in deciding the NPP levels30 although a delayed effect is seen in the study (Table S8). Precipitation also indirectly decides the magnitude of NDVI, EVI, LAI, and FPAR through edaphic factors. The consequent delayed impact on vegetation health due to reduced precipitation is because it takes time to influence soil moisture followed by vegetation indices. Optimal temperature is necessary for balanced NPP as either extremes in temperature will cause stress, reducing NPP. LST can directly influence the plant temperature along with the soil moisture. An increased plant respiration and evapotranspiration leading to duress in vegetation is seen in higher LST which is more apparent during periods of reduced PPT. NDVI and EVI which are fed by precipitation are measures of density and health of vegetation and rise with NPP. The drought study in India31,32, observed that there was a monsoon drought during the year 2002, which was also reflected in the NPP in the area in the subsequent year. This could have happened because the NPP is strongly related to the soil moisture and the soil moisture decreases significantly, affecting soil moisture recovery, and plant water availability.A noticeable dip in NPP in 2019 (Fig. 4) indicates a general declining trend in the productivity of forest areas, despite an overall increase in forests. The LAI for forests shows a slight increase from 2001 to 2022 but the increase is not substantial enough to offset the decline in NPP, suggesting that other factors (like tree density or health) might be influencing productivity. Another reason could be that due to the expansion of forest areas into less fertile regions or younger forests that are less productive. During the 2016–2019 period, when NPP dropped by 0.24 kg C m\(^{-2}\) year\(^{-1}\), a decline in vegetation health and productivity is observed through reduced NDVI and EVI (Fig. 9). The decline of NPP in Savannas had a change rate of \(-4.75\) to \(-4.99\)%, indicating a possibility of ecological shifts or substantial reduction in trees outside forests or sparse trees33 during that period (Fig. S2). Moderate impact of LST was observed in the croplands, influencing productivity to some extent while indices such as FPAR and LAI remained stable indicating consistent photosynthetic activity and vegetation cover. This period corresponds to a high negative change rate, suggesting severe ecological stress or conversion to other land uses. Since the NDVI and EVI show significant declines, confirming reduced vegetation health and productivity and also the higher temperatures during the critical period exacerbated stress. The significant reduction in barren land and a slight increase in water bodies suggest efforts in land reclamation or natural changes.The region witnessed a decreasing trend in nearly \(50\%\) of the area while \(29\%\) saw an increasing trend. The significantly increasing and decreasing pattern occupied about \(10\%\) and \(12\%\) respectively. The increasing trend is spread out mainly in the northern end of the boundary from Vansda all the way down to the Chandoli Forest which covers the states of Gujarat and Maharashtra. Towards the eastern half, the significance of the trend is more pronounced as the slope is favorable for agricultural practices in comparison to the northwestern part. The scattered distribution of a significantly increasing trend is also seen near Periyar region among others all of which are found along the periphery and characterised by low elevation and gentle slope. It is noticed that most of the consequential rises in NPP fall under the Tropical-Savanna and Arid-Steppe-Hot climatic zones. The savannas throughout the area, show a combination of increasing and decreasing trends. Forest prominently shows a decreasing and significantly decreasing trend. The highly downward trend of NPP is observed in the lower elevation of Tropical-monsoon and Tropical-Savanna zones in Karnataka and Kerala (Fig. 8).Fig. 8The NPP trend from 2001 to 2023 in the major LULC classes.Full size imageThe magnitude of influence of each factor is largely indirect as none of the factor shows more than \(18\%\) impact on NPP. It is clear that the anthropogenic factor indicated by LULC is the main variable in increasing NPP. Although it is common knowledge that the increase in human activity results in decreased forest cover and hence should bring down the NPP, this is not true in this case. We observe a rise in NPP prominently witnessed along the edges of the boundary where there is an increase in cropland which is a vital contributor. A high value of annual average NPP is found in the built-up as croplands surround them. The interaction detector aids in comprehending how each pair of variables impacts NPP detailed in Table 6. The type of interaction helps to understand whether the combined effects of variables are synergistic, additive, or antagonistic. All interactions with PPT result in a nonlinear enhancement, indicating a strong synergistic effect where the combination of PPT with other variables (like TEMP, LULC, etc.) produces a higher impact than the sum of their individual impacts. Most interactions involving TEMP result in a bi-variable enhancement, showing that the combined impact is greater than the individual impacts but less than their sum. The interaction with other variables such as vegetation indices (EVI, NDVI) and land use (LULC) suggests that moderate temperature changes, when combined with optimal land use and vegetation conditions, can significantly boost NPP. However, the interaction with slope results in a uni-variable weaken, indicating a weaker combined effect. LULC interactions show a bi-variable enhancement for all combinations, suggesting the interaction amplifies the effects but not to the extent of their sum. This highlights the significant role of land use practices and vegetation cover in modulating ecological productivity. Proper management and conservation of land resources in the Western Ghats can enhance the positive effects of climatic variables on NPP. EVI, NDVI, LST, LAI, and FPAR interactions generally exhibit bi-variable enhancement except when combined with slope, where a nonlinear enhance is observed. When combined with slope, the interactions show nonlinear enhancement, indicating that in areas with varied topography, the presence of healthy vegetation can lead to significantly higher NPP.Despite the linear relationship linking EVI and NDVI, there is a striking difference in their impact on NPP which can be explained by the ability of EVI to highlight the thick vegetation cover. The MLR model revealed that NDVI had the highest estimate followed by the intercept value. The coefficient for precipitation is highly significant and positive across most years which directly implies an increase in NPP. However, in some years, such as 2006 and 2018, the coefficient is negative, suggesting that other factors might be interacting with precipitation to reduce NPP in those years. LST coefficients are consistently negative and highly significant, indicating that higher land surface temperatures generally reduce NPP.Fig. 9The graphical representation of the result features the impact of different parameters in creating altering scenarios of NPP in the region. The NPP during 2003–2005 showed a decrease for a prolonged duration owing to increased LST, along with a decline in the indicated variables. In the years 2011, and 2022 a similar condition of higher NPP was recorded. This was preceded by high rainfall and reduced LST and temperature. The NPP witnessed the worst conditions in 2019 with very high temperatures and LST scenarios coupled with moderate rainfall and NDVI.Full size imageConclusionThe key indicators of NPP were PPT, NDVI, and LAI affecting positively, while EVI, and LST had generally a negative impact. The temperature displayed a varying effect depending on the year. The influence of predictors like temperature and precipitation on NPP is not uniform across years. This variability can be attributed to different environmental conditions, such as soil moisture, nutrient availability, and interaction with other climate factors. The consistently negative EVI coefficients suggest a complex dynamic where densely vegetated areas might not always translate to higher productivity. The power of the anthropogenic factor proved to be the highest followed by vegetation parameters driven by climatic conditions and barely any by the topographic indicator. The results from the interaction detector indicate that the interplay of precipitation, temperature, LULC, and vegetation indices significantly amplify NPP, highlighting the critical role of these variables in driving ecological productivity. The reduction in cropland area reflects ongoing changes in land use patterns within the Western Ghats, necessitating sustainable land management practices to maintain and potentially enhance cropland productivity amidst environmental and anthropogenic pressures. Although the average NPP of the Western Ghats saw a large drop in 2019, the ecological resilience helped the NPP to bounce back to the normal level by 2020. The NPP is decreasing in the forests even though the forests are increasing which may be attributed to the introduction of newer and younger forests. Apart from the chosen parameters, NPP is also influenced by soil moisture, \(CO_2\) level, humidity, dew point temperature, soil type and quality, wind, ecosystem type, and more. Future studies including all these parameters will provide more insights into the dynamics of NPP. In conclusion, the Western Ghats’ productivity is shaped by a combination of climatic variables, land use changes, and vegetation health. Effective management and conservation strategies are essential to mitigate the negative impacts and enhance the positive effects of these factors on NPP. The findings underscore the need for a holistic approach to preserve the biodiversity hotspot and sustain its ecological productivity. From a policy perspective, the results indicate a need to build a strong local governance through community based conservation efforts, and effective landscape level zoning. To sustain the forest productivity, as strict and locally driven conservation practices should be implemented to monitor the changing land use pattern. Integrating sustainable practices with stronger policy enforcement will be key to preserving the resilience of this critical biodiversity hotspot. The research underscores the urgency of integrating climate resilience into conservation strategies for the Western Ghats, renowned for its biodiversity and ecological importance, in response to significant climate threats.MethodsStudy areaThe Western Ghats boasts of being a landscape with rich ecological diversity sustaining all the forest classifications from grasslands to tropical wet evergreen forests, flowering plants having about 4000 different species, and ample fauna34. The forest types in the Western Ghats characterized as non-equatorial tropical evergreen forests have four major phenological attributes. The majority of the area is occupied by moist deciduous forests succeeded by semi-evergreen forests which have a greater level of vegetation diversity, evergreen forests with maximum level of endemism, and lastly, the dry deciduous forests prevalent on the leeward side of the mountain34. The Western Ghats sees a shift in climate with proximity to the equator as the latitude changes from 8\(^\circ\) 07’ 58” N to 21\(^\circ\) 15’ 58” N and the longitude from 72\(^\circ\) 53’ 31” E to 78\(^\circ\) 03’ 45” E (Fig. 10). The area expands from the coastline to a height of 2619 m above the mean sea level witnessing a range of topographic and climatic conditions. Stretching to a length of approximately 1500 Km, the study area stretches for 107,770 sq km from the southern tip of India, the Kanyakumari in Kerala to south of Gujarat including the Maharashtra, Goa, Karnataka, and Tamilnadu states35. The annual average precipitation is about 190 cm whereas the mean maximum and minimum precipitation is about 590 cm and 40 cm respectively. The minimum and maximum temperature in the region average 15 \(^\circ\)C and 30 \(^\circ\)C respectively while the annual average is around 26 \(^\circ\)C. This mountain range surfaced as a significant uplift along a rift shoulder during the Deccan Trap volcanic activity at the boundary between the Late Cretaceous and Paleocene epochs36. Owing to the tectonic action during the formation period, the northern and southern Western Ghats display contrasting geology with the Deccan traps consisting of basalt in the north and Charnockites, Granulites, Khondalites, etc in the south34.Fig. 10The research site accessorized with the climate classification and elevation.Full size imageDataTerrestrial productivity in the Western Ghats is quantified using NPP as the primary indicator. To understand the influence of various factors on NPP, the climate indicators (precipitation, air temperature, and land surface temperature), topography (slope), vegetation indices (NDVI, EVI, LAI, and FPAR), and anthropogenic factors, specifically Land Use and Land Cover (LULC) changes were examined (Table S2).NPPThe NPP refers to the fuel, fiber, and food source for the sustenance of human life. The spatial variation in the terrestrial biological productivity is crucial for measuring the global change pointing to the CO\(_2\) levels. This variation spans from approximately 30 gCm\(^{-2}\) for desert landscapes to as high as 1000 gCm\(^{-2}\) for the lush evergreen tropical rain forests. The product’s design is aimed to precisely measure the growth or activity of the terrestrial vegetation on a regular interval. Three major components form the basis for estimating terrestrial NPP from satellites. They include the direct relation of NPP to the absorbed solar energy, the theoretical link between satellite-derived vegetation characteristics and the absorbed solar energy, and the dissection of the reason for fluctuation in the efficiency of final conversion37.The MOD17A3H MODIS/Terra Net Primary Production Yearly L4 Global 500 m product was used in the study. The crop productivity shows a linear relation with the quantity of the absorbed solar energy and the absorbed Photosynthetically Active Radiation (APAR) according to the radiation use efficiency logic proposed by Monteith38 which forms the basis for the MOD17 algorithm. The actual productivity is estimated by translating the APAR using the conversion efficiency parameter, \(\epsilon\), which is determined by the climatic condition and vegetation type. MOD17 also calculates the respiration parameters. The improved version of the MOD17 algorithm (Collection 6.1) replaces the LAI product (\(LAI_{max}\)) dependent growth respiration (\(R_g\)) with \(R_g = 0.25*NPP\) for the calculation of MODIS NPP. \(R_g\) is the cost of energy used for organic compound construction. This upgrade reduces the mishap where the \(R_g\) value would be greater than NPP at times when the MODIS \(LAI_{max}\) would be set at 6.8 for the forest pixels39.$$\begin{aligned} N=G-R_m-R_g=G-R_m-0.25*N \end{aligned}$$
                    (1)
                where, N stands for Net Primary Productivity, G for Gross Primary Productivity, and \(R_m\) and \(R_g\) stand for annual plant maintenance respiration and growth respiration respectively.$$\begin{aligned} \begin{aligned} N&=0.8*(G-R_m) \quad when \quad G-R_m\ge 0, \quad and\\ N&=0 \quad \quad \quad \quad \quad \quad \quad \,\,\,\, when \quad G-R_m<0 \end{aligned} \end{aligned}$$
                    (2)
                PrecipitationMulti-Source Weighted-Ensemble Precipitation, version 2 (MSWEP V2)40 gridded precipitation product provides 3 hourly global data since 1979 with \(0.1^\circ\) spatial resolution. The data is formulated by merging the precipitation estimates from multiple sources such as the gauge data, satellite, and reanalysis products. To enhance the accuracy in the frequency of precipitation, bias correction methods, and correction for regional variations are introduced. The spatial pattern of magnitude, frequency, and mean precipitation demonstrated by MSWEP V2 is highly realistic. Precipitation datasets usually underestimate the magnitude in regions with mountains which is overcome by MSWEP V2.TemperatureThe MSWX is the Multi-Source Weather near-surface global meteorological product for temperature with 3-h temporal resolution and \(0.1^\circ\) spatial resolution41. The data is bias-corrected and with the help of reference climatological data, it is also down-scaled. The temperature information is obtained through a process based on cumulative distribution function (CDF)-matching. This process entails resampling the model data to 0.1\(^\circ\) using nearest neighbor interpolation, converting the model data to indices via a static matrix of evenly spaced data points, choosing the relevant correction factors from another static matrix of correction factors based on these indices, and finally, applying these correction factors to the model data through multiplication.LULCThis data plays a crucial role in understanding the changing features of the region. The Annual International Geosphere-Biosphere Programme (IGBP) classification from the MODIS Land Cover data (MCD12Q1.061) which has a 500 m spatial resolution and 17 classes is adopted for the study. The dataset is created and prepared by applying a decision tree algorithm based on the combination of MODIS NDVI, surface reflectance, albedo band parameters, and land surface temperature42. For the purpose of the study, as the 2023 LULC was not available, 2022 LULC was used for 2023 as well. The IGBP classification has 17 classes which were grouped into 9 classes based on their characteristics for better interpretation and understanding (Table S2).NDVIThe MODIS NDVI product (MOD13Q1.061) is available with a spatial resolution of 500 m at 16-day intervals. The usage of NDVI in the biogeochemical and circulation models is crucial at all scales from local to global43.$$\begin{aligned} NDVI = \frac{\rho _{NIR}-\rho _{red}}{\rho _{NIR}+\rho _{red}} \end{aligned}$$
                    (3)
                where variables \(\rho _{NIR}\) and \(\rho _{RED}\) represent the bidirectional reflectance factors for the corresponding MODIS bands at the surface level.EVIEVI is a vegetation monitoring tool with higher sensitivity than NDVI. The MODIS EVI product (MOD13Q1.061) uses the sensor’s near-infrared (\(\rho _{NIR}\)), red (\(\rho _{red}\)), and blue (\(\rho _{blue}\)) bands. It is beneficial in studying the vegetation characteristics such as phenology, stress, and productivity in areas of dense biomass as it reduces the influence of atmosphere and surpasses the saturation problem present in NDVI. The calculation of EVI involves the soil-adjustment factor, coefficients of variation adjustments, and canopy background adjustments44.Land surface temperature (LST)The MODIS LST product (MOD11A2.061) which is a 8 day 1 Km resolution data is derived using the generalized split-window algorithm. Based on the land cover types, and atmospheric column water vapour, lower boundary air surface temperature, the 31 and 32 bands are estimated for the emissivities. Manageable sub-ranges of temperatures are calculated for efficient retrieval45.LAI and FPARThe LAI and FPAR products from MODIS (MOD15A2H.061) are developed from surface reflectances using the vegetation canopy radiative transfer algorithm46. This was put into implementation before the launch of MODIS on the TERRA platform.Digital elevation model (DEM)A globally continuous DEM with 30 m spatial resolution depends on applying radar interferometry algorithms to the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) data, which is then processed into a locally spherical coordinate system47.Experimental frameworkTrend analysisThe Mann Kendall (MK) test48,49 is applied to analyze the trend of the time series NPP data from 2001 to 2023. The nonparametric test checks for an increasing or a decreasing trend, along with the significance and monotonicity of the statistics. The trend may or may not be linear. The MK test holds an advantage over the regression analysis which requires the residual data to be normally distributed. The trend present is quantified by testing if the time series falls within the confidence interval which is given by the null hypothesis and the significance level50.$$\begin{aligned} S=\sum _{k=1}^{j-1} \sum _{l=k+1}^{j} sgn(a_l-a_k) \end{aligned}$$
                    (4)
                where the length of the NPP data is represented as j, while \(a_l\) and \(a_k\) are the sequential data values.$$\begin{aligned} sgn(a_l-a_k) = {\left\{ \begin{array}{ll} 1, if(a_l-a_k) >0\\ 0, if(a_l-a_k) =0\\ -1, if(a_l-a_k)<0 \end{array}\right. } \end{aligned}$$
                    (5)
                The mean is given as E(S) and variance as Var(S), with the random distribution of the variable, the normal distribution is approximated when \(j\ge 8\).$$\begin{aligned} & E(S)=0 \end{aligned}$$
                    (6)
                $$\begin{aligned} & \quad Var(S) = \frac{j(j-1)(2j+5)-\sum _{k=1}^{m}d_k(d_k-1)(2d_k+5)}{18} \end{aligned}$$
                    (7)
                where for the extent k, \(d_k\) is the number of ties and m is the number of tie groups. \(Z_S\) denotes the test statistics.$$\begin{aligned} Z_S = {\left\{ \begin{array}{ll} \frac{S-1}{\sqrt{Var(S)}}, if S>0\\ 0, if S=0\\ \frac{S+1}{\sqrt{Var(S)}}, if S<0\\ \end{array}\right. } \end{aligned}$$
                    (8)
                The result of the test reveals an increasing and decreasing trend with a positive and negative \(Z_S\) respectively. A test uses a confidence level of \(95\%\) with an \(\alpha\) value of 0.05.GDMSpatial heterogeneity is a fundamental characteristic of geographic phenomena. The models are statistically designed to detect spatially stratified heterogeneity and uncover the underlying driving forces27. The analysis of the spatial variability is covered by the GDM using the four geographical detectors. It is used to assess the influence of climatic and meteorological parameters on the productivity of the forest through geographical strata. The areas of risk are identified by the risk detector, and the factor responsible for it is recognized by the factor detector. The relative prominence of the parameters is revealed by the ecological factor and the interaction detector decides if a parameter can independently contribute to the fluctuation in the change in NPP51.Factor detectorIt is used to determine how much each natural factor contributes to the spatial distribution of NPP. The goal is to assess how each natural factor individually impacts the spatial distribution of NPP. The methodology involves several steps: first, spatial superposition and analysis of the NPP layer and natural factor layers; second, division of the natural factors into different spatial categories or classes; and finally, calculation of the mean differences of these natural factors. The significance test is then used to determine the relative importance of each natural factor. The F-test determines if there is a significant difference in the variances.$$\begin{aligned} F=\frac{\sigma ^2_{A,\, p}}{\sigma ^2_{A,\ r}} \end{aligned}$$
                    (9)
                where, \(\sigma ^2_{A,\, p}\) is the dispersion variance, and \(\sigma ^2_{A,\ r}\) is the stratified population dispersion variance. The geographical strata are defined as r and p is the sample units in each strata, while A represents the variable.$$\begin{aligned} B_{WG}=q=1-\frac{\sigma ^2_{A,\, r}}{\sigma ^2_{A,\, p}} \end{aligned}$$
                    (10)
                \(B_{WG}\) is the power of determinant of z to the NPP. As the q value (\(0< q < 1\)) increases, so does the influence of the influence of the factor.Interaction detectorThe detector explains the factor \(A'\) and \(A{''}\) on the NPP. The procedure involved the following steps: first, we computed the q values for \(A'\) and \(A{''}\), denoted as \(q(A')\) and \(q(A{''})\), respectively. The interaction between the two factors is calculated as \((q(A' \cap \, A{''}))\) to understand the type of interaction. In this study, we used the interactive detector to measure the coupling effect of topography and climate factors on NPP51,52. The criteria to segregate the values into interaction types is detailed in Table 7.Table 7 The conditions to realize the impact of pairwise combined effect on NPP is described. The effects of individual variables are non-linearly diminished by the interaction of two variables (\(NL\cdot Wn\)). The effects of individual variables are weakened by single-variable interactions (\(UV\cdot Wn\)). The effects of individual variables are enhanced by two-variable interactions (\(BV\cdot Enh\)). The impacts of variables operate independently of each other (IN). The effects of variables are amplified in a non-linear manner (\(NL\cdot Enh\)).Full size tableRisk detectorIt is employed to determine if there was a notable difference in the mean attribute between two subregions of each factor and to identify areas where NPP had either declined or improved. t-test53. The risk for the geographical zone r is defined as \(Z_r\). The t-test is carried out with number of samples p in the r zone as \(n_{r,p}\)$$\begin{aligned} t_{\overline{Z_{r=1}}-\overline{Z_{r=2}}} = \frac{\overline{Z_{r=1}}-\overline{Z_{r=2}}}{\left[ \frac{1}{d_{r=1,\, p}}\sigma ^2_{\overline{Z_{r=1}}}+\frac{1}{d_{r=2,\, p}}\sigma ^2_{\overline{Z_{r=2}}}\right] ^{1/2}} \end{aligned}$$
                    (11)
                degree of freedom$$\begin{aligned} df=\frac{\left[ \frac{1}{d_{r=1,p}}\sigma ^2_{\overline{Z_{r=1}}}+\frac{1}{d_{r=2,\, p}}\sigma ^2_{\overline{Z_{r=2}}}\right] }{\frac{1}{d_{r=1,\, p^{-1}}} \left[ \frac{1}{d_{r=2,\, p}}\sigma ^2_{\overline{Z_{r=1}}} \right] ^2 + \frac{1}{d_{r=2,\, p^{-1}}} \left[ \frac{1}{d_{r=2,\, p}}\sigma ^2_{\overline{Z_{r=2}}} \right] ^2} \end{aligned}$$
                    (12)
                null hypothesis \(H_0: \overline{Z_{r=1}}=\overline{Z_{r=2}}\)if \(\left| t_{\overline{Z_{r=1}}-\overline{Z_{r=2}}} \right| > t_{\alpha /2}\)Ecological detectorThe model aimed to assess if the impact of any two factors on the evolution of NPP varied significantly. The analysis determined whether \(A_1\) had a greater effect on the spatial distribution of NPP compared to \(A_2\), using the F statistic for measurement. The dispersion variance for \(A_1\) and \(A_2\) are defined as \(\sigma ^2_{A_1,\, r} = \frac{1}{d_{A_1,\, p}}\sum _{r=1}^{d_{A_1,\, r}}\sum _{p=1}^{d_{r,\, p}}\left( Z_{A_1, \,p} - \overline{Z_{A_1,\, p}}\right) ^2\) and \(\sigma ^2_{A_2,\, r} = \frac{1}{d_{A_2,\, p}}\sum _{r=1}^{d_{A_2,\, r}}\sum _{p=1}^{d_{r,\, p}}\left( Z_{A_2, \,p} - \overline{Z_{A_2,\, p}}\right) ^2\) respectively. The test is defined as$$\begin{aligned} F=\frac{d_{A_1,\, p}(d_{A_1,\, p}-1)\sigma ^2_{A_1,\, r}}{d_{A_2,\, p}(d_{A_2,\, p}-1)\sigma ^2_{A_2,\, r}} \end{aligned}$$
                    (13)
                Multiple linear regression (MLR)Analyzing the impact of multiple independent variables on one dependent variable is achieved through the MLR54,55. The regression assumes that the dependent variable is directly related to a linear combination of the explanatory variables. The regression model is formulated as:$$\begin{aligned} x=\beta _0+\beta _1y_1+\cdots +\beta _ny_n+\epsilon \end{aligned}$$
                    (14)
                where x is the dependent variable, and \(y_i\) is the independent variable. When all the explanatory variables are 0, \(\beta _0\) is the constant of the dependent variable. \(\beta _i\) is the coefficient of the explanatory variable and \(\epsilon\) is the error coefficient. The t value is the representation of the test statistics of the two-sided t-test. The likelihood of the result to have occurred by chance is inversely related to the t value.The validation of the MLR model fitness assumes that there is a low or nonexistent correlation between the explanatory variables. The data set is checked to fulfill the assumptions for MLR. Independent observations are made, the variance of residuals is constant throughout the linear model, and normal distribution is observed for the residual of the model. A nearly linear relationship is seen between the explanatory variables and NPP. The residual values are estimated very close to zero and the data is nearly equally distributed on both the positive and the negative side which reiterates the assumption of the data upholding heteroscedasticity. The Pearson correlation was used to test for multicollinearity, which indicated that LAI and FPAR produced a very high positive correlation (> 0.7) and hence theoretically it was not suitable to be used. So an alternate MLR model was derived by excluding the LAI and FPAR parameters. The resulting plot did not show any significant change. Also when comparing the \(R^2\) value, the model with all the parameters showed a high value of \(R^2\) which meant that the model was a better fit for the dataset. Also, the model with all the parameters had a smaller RMSE value. In conclusion, despite the independent parameters of LAI and FPAR having a high correlation with each other, they were utilized in the MLR since removing them did not have any benefit in the model performance. From the results obtained from \(R^2\), RMSE, Adjusted \(R^2\), MAE, Average RMSE across 10 folds, AIC value, BIC value it is deduced that despite the assumption not being completely satisfied, the model with all the parameters is the best-fitted model.

Data availability
              
              All data were sourced from open-access databases, with detailed information provided in the supplementary file. The MODIS NPP data is available from https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/mod17a3hgfv061/. The precipitation dataset can be accessed from https://www.gloh2o.org/mswep/. The temperature is obtained through https://www.gloh2o.org/mswx/. The LULC data is available via https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/mcd12q1v061/. The EVI and NDVI products are made accessible through https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/mod13q1v061/. The LST data is procured from https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/mod11a2v061/. The LAI and FPAR datasets are made available at https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/mod15a2hv061/. The elevation product was obtained from https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/products/srtmgl1v003/.
